fields.headline: Kennedy's highs and lows
fields.bodyText: Highs · Elected to parliament at the age of only 23 in 1983 to represent Ross, Cromarty and Skye for the SDP · Astutely backed the 1987 merger of the SDP with the Liberals to form the SDP/Liberal Alliance · Increased the Lib Dems' share of the vote to 18.3% in the 2001 general election, giving the party 52 seats at Westminster and a strong presence in the Scottish parliament and Welsh assembly · Consistently opposed the war in Iraq and was proved right about WMDs - a stance that proved the Lib Dems' biggest asset in the 2005 general election Lows · Missed the budget in 2004 due to ill health. "He's not Paddy Ashdown. Paddy Ashdown, I think, was never ill," said the Lib Dem president, Simon Hughes · Ridiculed for his confused explanation of the Lib Dems' "transparent" tax policies during the 2005 election campaign. Commentators did not accept the birth of his first child as an excuse · Disappointing 2005 general election result led to accusations of over-indulgence in alcohol and laziness. · Failed to quell briefings against him in December 2005, despite assurances that he would change his leadership style and reinvigorate the party in the face of the resurgent Tories.
